All are only concomitant with the faculty of equanimity.
As for the three times:
All are common to the three times.
As for taking the three times as objects:
The first eight all-encompassing bases take the past as objects in the past.
The present takes the present as objects. The future takes the future as objects if they are dharmas that have arisen.
If they are dharmas that have not arisen, they take the three times as objects.
The last two all-encompassing bases both take the three times as objects.
As for wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate:
All are only wholesome. As for taking wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate as objects:
The first eight all-encompassing bases take the three kinds as objects.
The last two all-encompassing bases take wholesome and indeterminate as objects.
As for being bound to the three realms and being unbound:
The first eight all-encompassing bases are only bound to the form realm.
The last two bases of totality are only bound to the formless realm.
They take as objects those bound to the three realms and those unbound.
The first eight bases of totality only take as objects those bound to the desire realm.
The last two bases of totality only take as objects those bound to the formless realm.
As for whether they are of the learner, post-learner, or neither learner nor post-learner,
they are all only neither learner nor post-learner.
As for whether they take as objects those of the learner, post-learner, or neither learner nor post-learner,
they all only take as objects those of neither learner nor post-learner.
As for whether they are eliminated by seeing, eliminated by cultivation, or not eliminated,
they are all only eliminated by cultivation.
As for whether they take as objects those eliminated by seeing, eliminated by cultivation, or not eliminated,
the first eight bases of totality only take as objects those eliminated by cultivation.
The last two bases of totality take as objects those eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
As for whether they take names as objects or meanings as objects,
they all take meanings as objects.
As for whether they take one's own continuity, another's continuity, or no continuity as objects,
the first eight bases of totality
Some say
only take another's continuity as objects.
Some say they take one's own and another's continuity as objects.
The last two universal bases are both associated with oneself and others.
As for the attainment through practice and the attainment through detachment,
all are both attained through practice and attained through detachment.
As for the attainment through detachment,
the first eight universal bases are attained when one detaches from the third trance state.
The ninth universal base is attained when one detaches from the fourth trance state.
The tenth universal base is attained when one detaches from the sphere of infinite space.
Later, they manifest through practice.
As for the attainment through practice, they are attained through practice,
and also manifest through practice.
ÅšrÄvakas may either manifest through middling practice
or through superior practice.
Pratyekabuddhas manifest through inferior practice.
Buddhas neither attain nor manifest through practice.
As for the previously attained and the not previously attained,
all are both previously attained and not previously attained.
This means that noble ones and those of the inner teachings who are ordinary beings are both previously attained and not previously attained.
Those of the outer teachings who are ordinary beings are only previously attained.
Question: What is the practice of these ten universal bases?
Answer: The first four universal bases take eye consciousness as their practice.
When they are fully accomplished, they take the four objects of form, blue, yellow, red, and white as their objects.
The middle four universal bases take body consciousness as their practice.
When they are fully accomplished, they take the four objects of touch, earth, water, fire, and wind as their objects.
There is an explanation:
The first seven universal bases take eye consciousness as their practice.
One of the middle universal bases takes body consciousness as its practice.
Why is this?
The universal bases of earth, water, and fire.
Take shape and visible form as their objects.
The universal base of wind takes movement and touch as its object.
There is another explanation:
The first eight universal bases all take eye consciousness as their practice.
Why is this?
Because the universal base of wind also takes form as its object.
As the world says:
East wind, south wind, west wind, north wind.
Wind with dust, wind without dust.
Vaisnava wind.ğŸ”½VÄyu wind.
Wind wheel wind, etc.
Therefore, the all-encompassing concentration on wind also takes the form of the wind element as its object.
The sphere of infinite space takes space as its preparatory practice.
The sphere of infinite consciousness takes consciousness as its preparatory practice.
Thus, the general characteristics of the all-encompassing concentrations have been explained.
The individual characteristics of each should now be briefly explained.
In all that is blue, whether above, below, or to the side,
there is no duality, no measure.
One gives rise to the thought of blue, which is the first all-encompassing concentration.
All that is blue
refers to all blue forms, whether small or large, collectively called blue.
Above refers to the upper direction.
Below refers to the lower direction.
To the side refers to the four cardinal directions and the four intermediate directions. No duality means
that the characteristics are purely blue, without any admixture.ğŸ”½No measure means
that there is no limit.
One gives rise to the thought of blue means
that by means of the superior intention and attention, one gives rise to the thought of blue in all places.
Which is the first all-encompassing concentration means
The first is that the sequence of names and numbers is at the beginning.
Or entering this concentration is at the beginning in sequence.
That is to say, when entering this concentration, all wholesome form, feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness are collectively called universal bases.
Like the universal base of blue, and so on, is explained in detail.
Up to the universal base of infinite consciousness is also like this.
There is a difference.
The last two universal bases should not speak of form.
One should only speak of the aggregates of feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness.
Question: The first eight universal bases may have above and below.
Because the objects they take as their objects have spatial locations.
The last two universal bases take emptiness and consciousness as their objects.
Since the objects they take as their objects have no spatial locations above and below,
how can it be said that they have above and below?
Answer: Although the objects taken as objects by the last two universal bases have no above and below or spatial locations,
the concentration they rely on has three grades.
Therefore, it can be said to have above and below.ğŸ”½Above refers to relying on superior concentration.
Below refers to relying on inferior concentration.
Furthermore, the word side refers to relying on middling concentration.
Furthermore, the practitioner.
The place where the body resides has above and below, so it can be said to have above, below, and sides.
What are the matters such as place? The lower one resides among humans.
The middle one resides in the Heaven of the Four Kings.
The upper one resides in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
In this way, up to the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others, they are mutually referred to as lower, middle, and upper.
The upper one is called upper.
The lower one is called lower.
The middle one is called side.
Why is there no liberation, mastery, or universal sphere in the third concentration?
The answer is: because it is not a field, and so on.
Furthermore, in the first concentration of the desire realm,
it is because it attracts the craving for form of the aggregate of consciousness.
Therefore, the liberation and mastery of the first two concentrations take the impure as their object.
Because the second and third concentrations do not attract the craving for form of the aggregate of consciousness,
the third and fourth concentrations
do not establish the liberation and mastery of the impure form as their object.
The first three dhyanas have vitarka, vicara, priti, and sukha.
And because the in-and-out breath disturbs them, there is no pure liberation.

The last four deliverances, the first eight spheres of mastery, and the first eight totalities take pure and wonderful objects as their objects and are able to subdue afflictions. This is very difficult.
Therefore, one must rely on the stage free from disturbance in order to accomplish them.
Furthermore, the third dhyana is far from the desire realm.
And within the dhyanas, it is not the most excellent.
Therefore, there are no deliverances, spheres of mastery, or totalities. Furthermore, the third dhyana, like the third formless attainment,
has few merits and therefore no deliverances, etc.ğŸ”½That is to say, the sphere of infinite space and the sphere of infinite consciousness have the merit of the aspect of infinity.
The sphere of nothingness has the merit of the concentration of cessation.
The sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception has neither the aspect of infinity
nor the concentration of cessation.
Therefore, the merits of this stage are few. The third dhyana, like it, also has no merits of deliverances, spheres of mastery, or totalities.
Furthermore, in the third meditation there is the most excellent pleasure of life and death.
It can cause practitioners to become addicted and confused, so there are no superior and universal bases for liberation.
Question: If that is so, then there should be no other merits such as the immeasurables, supernormal powers, and so forth.
Answer: It is said that there are few merits, not that they are completely absent.
If this ground lacks the immeasurables and so forth, then this meditation would be empty of merits.
Furthermore, the immeasurables generally give rise to supernormal powers that play in this ground.
One attains the merits of the superior and universal bases for liberation.
The specific focus on form and so forth subdues the afflictions, but because it is difficult to accomplish, this ground lacks them.
As the sutra says:
Those who attain the universal concentration of the ground
Think like this:
The ground is precisely me, and I am precisely the ground.
The ground and I are non-dual and not separate.
Those who attain the other universal concentrations
Speak extensively in the same way according to their own focus.
Question: Those who attain the universal concentrations
Must have already become free from the defilements of the third meditation.
The self-view that arises from that must be the fourth meditation.
If it is the fourth meditation self-view,
it must only take the earth and other eight universal bases of the fourth meditation stage as objects.
But it takes only the form base of the desire realm as its object.
How can it be said to take the earth and so on as objects in the same way as that self-view?
There is an explanation:
Here, it is said that one who has not yet attained that concentration is one who has attained it.
Just as one who is not a Å›ramaá¹‡a is called a Å›ramaá¹‡a,
and one who is not a brÄhmaá¹‡a is called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.
That is to say, one who has not yet eliminated the afflictions of the desire realm,

and has not yet attained the fundamental earth and other universal bases,ğŸ”½practices the earth and other universal bases that are accomplished through hearing and contemplation in the desire realm for the first time.
Therefore, it is possible for him to give rise to a self-view that takes the earth and so on as objects.
Or there is an explanation:
It is also not contradictory to use the old name.
It is like a king
who, although he has lost his royal status,
is still called a king using his old name.
In the same way, one who has previously attained the universal bases such as the earth,
Even though they have now regressed and lost [the attainment], they are still called those who have attained it.
If they give rise to the view of self in the desire realm,
taking the desire realm and so forth as the self, there is no contradiction with reason.
There is another explanation.
Based on quickly entering and exiting the bases of totality and the view of self,
making such statements is also not contradictory.
This means that they first attain the bases of totality such as the earth base,
and later quickly regress and give rise to the view of self in the desire realm,
taking the desire realm and so forth as the self.
They quickly regain the bases of totality such as the fourth dhyana ground, and take the desire realm and so forth as their objects.
Like Devadatta, who first attained the dhyanas,
used the power of his spiritual penetrations to transform into a small child,
wearing secular clothes with golden threads, making five flower crowns,
playing on the lap of Prince Ajatashatru, rolling around and playing.
Still causing the prince to know that this was Venerable Devadatta.
At that time, Ajatashatru loved him and held him, playing with him.
He then spat into his mouth.
Devadatta, out of greed for profit, swallowed the saliva.
Therefore the Buddha scolded him, saying,
You are a corpse-eater who swallows human saliva.
When he swallowed the saliva, he immediately fell from meditative absorption.
He quickly regained it, causing the transformed body on the prince's lap to play as before.
One should understand the all-encompassing view of self to be the same as this.
Other masters say,
In this intermediate state, the body views the fourth meditative absorption and below as the self.
The first eight all-encompassing bases also take the fourth meditative absorption and below as objects.
Question: Aren't the first eight all-encompassing bases also taken as objects in the desire realm?
Answer: They are also taken as objects in the desire realm and also in the fourth meditative absorption.
Question: The gods in the form realm are pure and white in color.
How can they be taken as objects and made blue, etc.?
Answer: Sentient beings in the form realm are pure and white in color.
Non-sentient things there also have blue, etc.
The judges say,
They should not say this.
If there were a view of a real self associated with and coexisting with the eight universal bases,
one could raise the question of how these associated and coexisting dharmas
either take the fourth meditation as their object or take the desire realm as their object.
However, since the view of a real self and the first eight universal bases are neither associated nor coexisting, this question should not be raised.
One sentient being is called one who conceives of a self and is also called one who attains concentration.
Because of the view of a real self, he is called one who conceives of a self.
Because of the universal bases, he is called one who attains concentration.
The view of a real self takes the fourth meditation and other stages as a self.
Since the first eight universal bases take the form of the desire realm as their object, not simultaneously, this sÅ«tra is well explained.
This view of a real self and the first eight universal bases have the same basis in the body but different objects.
As a sÅ«tra says:
There is earth concentration, etc., and there are universal bases of earth, etc.
Question: What is the difference between these earth concentrations, etc., and the universal bases of earth, etc.?
Answer: The earth concentrations, etc., are in the desire realm and the four meditations, while the universal bases of earth, etc., are only in the fourth meditation.
Furthermore, when in the stage of preparation, it is called the concentration on earth, etc.
When perfected, it is called the universal sphere of earth, etc.
Furthermore, when it is a cause, it is called the concentration on earth, etc.
When it is a result, it is called the universal sphere of earth, etc.
Furthermore, when there is an understanding of a small part, it is called the concentration on earth, etc.
When there is an understanding of the all-pervasiveness, it is called the universal sphere of earth, etc.
This is the difference.
Question: What is the difference between the liberations, the spheres of mastery, and the universal spheres?
Answer: The names themselves are the difference. This is called liberation, this is called the spheres of mastery, and this is called the universal spheres.
Furthermore, the inferior wholesome roots are called liberation.ğŸ”½The middling wholesome roots are called the spheres of mastery.
The superior wholesome roots are called the universal spheres.
Furthermore, the small wholesome roots are called liberation.
The great wholesome roots are called the spheres of mastery.
The immeasurable wholesome roots are called the universal spheres.
Furthermore, only the causes are called liberation.
Only the results are called the universal spheres.
Both the causes and results are called the spheres of mastery.
Furthermore, that which can abandon and turn away is called liberation.
The name conquering the object is conquering the object.
The name extending the object is extending the object.
Furthermore, only the name liberation is liberation.ğŸ”½The name conquering the object is conquering the object.
The name extending the object is extending the object.
Furthermore, if one attains liberation, one may not necessarily have already attained conquering the object and extending the object.
If one attains conquering the object, one must have already attained liberation.
One may not necessarily have already attained extending the object.
If one attains extending the object, one must have already attained liberation and conquering the object.
Why is it so?
From liberation one enters conquering the object.
From conquering the object one enters extending the object.
Therefore, this is the difference between liberation, conquering the object, and extending the object.
